Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Low-temperature Spin Spray Synthesized Magnetoelectric Nanocomposite Films for Novel RF and Microwave Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
ECCS-0746810
Nian Sun, Northeastern University

The objective of this research is to investigate novel magnetoelectric composite films and explore their applications in integrated RF and microwave magnetoelectric devices. The approach is to use the spin spray plating, which has been demonstrated to produce high quality microwave ferrite films at low temperatures and at a low cost. The strong magnetoelectric coupling and the many recent breakthroughs in magnetoelectric composites comprising both ferri/ferromagnetic and ferroelectric phases have made this area extremely exciting.

Intellectual Merit: Low-temperature processing of the magnetoelectric films is critical in order for them to be used in integrated circuits which have tight temperature control. This project proposes to investigate novel spin-spray synthesis methods for magnetoelectric films at a low temperature of 80~90?aC. These magnetoelectric films will be characterized at different length scales and across different frequency bands, which will be applied in novel integrated RF/microwave magnetoelectric devices. This project will lead to a whole new area of spin-spray deposited magnetoelectric films and novel integrated tunable magnetoelectric devices for RF/microwave integrated circuits.

Broader Impacts: Spin-spray deposited magnetoelectric films will lead to new functionalities on integrated circuits that ferroelectric or magnetic materials alone do not possess, and will have great impacts on many industries and on society. The education plan includes establishing the Magic of Magnetism program for the Museum of Science, Boston; and an extensive K ~ graduate education plan including graduate and undergraduate education, research experiences for undergraduates, high school students and teachers, emphasizing participation of underrepresented groups, particularly women and minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award ECCS 0746810 has produced significant project outcome and great impacts. The project outcome on research includes the synthesis, characterization and applications of novel magnetoelectric ferrite/ferroelectric multiferroic heterostructures produced by low-temperature spin-spray synthesis method. These low-temperature spin spray deposition process leads to fully dense diffusion-free ferrite/ferroelectric interface with strong atomic bonding, which enables strong magnetoelectric coupling with effective voltage control of magnetism in ferrite/ferroelectric heterostructures. At the same time, a whole series of multiferroic devices have been demonstrated in this project, which were compact, lightweight, and power efficient compared to state of the art magnetic devices that are tuned by magnetic fields. More than 50 journal papers and more than 20 conference papers have been published during the funding period, together with several patent applications that are being processed. One of the papers funded by this NSF award was selected as "the 10 most outstanding full papers in the past ten years (2001~2010) in Advanced Functional Materials". At the same time, there have been more than 30 invited or keynote presentations on the funded research in this project. The PI was also awarded the Søren Buus Outstanding Research Award in 2012.

 

The PI has been putting a great amount effort on K ~ Graduate education in particular on educating the underrepresented groups. This project has led to three Ph.D. graduates that were (partially) funded by this NSF award. There were >10 female or minority African-American students involved in this project in the PI’s group supported by this NSF award. At the same time, there has been >10 high school students and 10 high school teachers that participated in this project. The PI also worked closely with local public schools in different outreach activities, including science fairs, etc. In addition, The PI has also developed the Magic of Magnetism program together with the Cahners Computer Place at the Museum of Science. The link of the Magic of Magnetism program is at: http://www.neu.edu/sunlab/mom/magic_of_magnetism.html. This website has since been very well visited, and we got excellent feedbacks from a lot people, including high school teachers, students, etc. Here is one quote from a high school teacher from the Dover-Sherborn Middle School, MA: “Thanks so much! It is the BEST page on magnetism I have found.” 

 

The project outcome on research and on education has great impacts on technology and on society. These spin spray deposited ferrite/ferroelectric multiferroic heterostructures have led to new functionalities on voltage control of magnetism or magnetic field control of electric polarization. In particular, the voltage control of magnetism has led to much more compact, lightweight and power efficient magnetic devices that are controlled by a voltage, instead of by magnetic field. Great impacts are expected with these multiferroic heterostructures, which will lead to more compact and power efficient novel voltage tunable RF/microwave devices and spintronic devices, and much longer battery life for smart phones, tablets, etc. The K ~ graduate education efforts have led to well-trained Ph.D. graduates on magnetic, ferroelectric and multiferroic materials and devices which are widely used in different industries.
